text: Please take your time to follow this video up with climate-change political scientists and negotiators. The issue of climate security has very unique challenges when it comes to making international agreements and treaties about it. In particular, it is a global public good. (read the books by Inge Kaul, et. al. called "Global Public Goods: International Cooperation in the 21st Century" if you want to learn more about the unique challenges issues like climate-change pose to global governance).

text: I just graduated with my biochemistry degree, but i have taken many classes on climate science and sustainability. During each class, i found myself consistently baffled at the lack of accountability and effort put into combatting climate change. We have so much evidence and so many possible solutions, yet we‚Äôve wasted decades arguing with each other. Humanity is doomed if we don‚Äôt do something immediately. Actually yesterday.

text:
Climate change is like the physical embodiment of anxiety. 

Once we get temporary relief from avoiding an issue, the problem comes back larger than the last time we blocked it out. 

The weight of the issue grows and grows and becomes more daunting the longer that we avoid it‚Äî until it is unavoidable.

I learned that type of management from therapy recently, and seeing a similar application towards climate change was eye-opening.

text: The way I've been able to visibly see climate change is the fact that there's no snow. I live in the north of Sweden and it's crazy how little snow we get now compared to when I was little. text:
Just a fair warning: David Keith is bad news. He's THE major proponent of geoengineering, which is heavily pushed by billionaires but the science shows any benefits would be negligible, while the risks are enormous. Carbon sequestration and reduction of emissions are both extremely necessary, and spraying aerosols in the sky to enact "radiative forcing" to force away the sun's rays is ludicrous. No one serious/ respected will actually push geoengineering. Keith does scholarship on carbon capture; I'm not saying his work is 100% bad, but the bad stuff is SERIOUSLY bad. 

AND BOOM AT 20:30 he talks about it. This makes me sick. "Wacky, controversial"... Yes. I saw David Keith speak in person in 2013. He said, in front of an audience (and this is recorded) that "geoengineering will kill people." This is not "wacky/controversial," this is a gross, seriously concerning experiment that must not be allowed to happen when there are SO MANY OTHER KNOWN OPTIONS AVAILABLE. Yes, plant trees!!! Sequester carbon in the VAST swaths of agricultural land that exist!!! Scientists already posit that the Earth could be returned to pre-industrial carbon levels in 50 years by raising the humus content of the soil (read Terra Preta by Ute Shueb et al.). We do NOT need geoengineering. We do NOT, under ANY circumstances, need to use technology to kill people to "solve climate change." 

This is GARBAGE. DO NOT PUSH GEOENGINEERING ON YOUR CHANNEL. Listen to scientists that don't describe themselves as "in Bill Gates' kitchen cabinet," as Keith did when I saw him in-person in 2013. Billionaires do not care about the people. 80% of the world's biodiversity is on 22% of the land, and this land happens to be legally controlled by Indigenous peoples. One of the best things people can do for climate change is return Indigenous sovereignty and Indigenous land control. The solutions exist. Geoengineering is seriously not one of them.

author: Brian Diehl

text:
Yes volcanos release a lot of carbon. But said carbon also goes back into the earth through carbon sinks and sequesters. The world we live in is built on balance. That's why the earth doesn't die when there's a volcano. Everything eventually works itself out. 

Boom humans came along, cutting down what once sucked up carbon. Burning down trees releases the once held carbon back into the atmosphere. Cattle farms as far as the eye can see in Brazil pumping methane into the atmosphere. Oil sands in the Arctic turning the once rich soil in infertile sludge and the water toxic. And all for what, short term profit, because humans don't give time for things to balance out. They just take and take, poisoning the soil, water and air. It's quite sad actually. Coral reefs are calcifying from acidic waters and rising sea levels, so now small islands inhabited by people are flooding. 

Carbon and other pollutants trap heat within the atmosphere, pollutants which would go away if we stop destroying so much of what is keeping the balance. That's why we need sustainability.

text:
That's great! But I'm biased because that's what I eat too... :D I have chicken or fish once a week because my acne goes haywire without it for some stupid reason, cheese for breakfast sandwiches, and butter and eggs for baking maybe twice a month. Other than that, yeah, basically vegan I guess...

But about the protein though, it's a bit silly to worry about not getting enough protein, because most people actually go waay over the minimum amount the human body requires every day. Which isn't unhealthy, but sometimes unnecessary. B-12 vitamin is a lot more important to try to supplement if you don't eat meat often or at all. But protein? You pretty much get all you need from grains, vegetables and nuts if you incorporate a good amount of those into your diet. But it's a whole other thing if you're trying to gain muscle mass or lose weight, of course, because in those instances you should try to get a lot more protein than the basic recommended amount. Fat is also super easy to get from nuts or oils, so you wouldn't necessarily need eggs or fish for that either. But yeah, those are just some "cool food facts". I'm sure your diet is already good as it is, but yeah :)

text:
Read it all before you reply please!

Just because people have spent hundreds of years of study on carbon emissions, doesn't change the FACT that glacial advacments and retreats have been happening over millions of years...

Yes, carbon in the air has increased. Yes, it is caused by human..

But how does it make sense that it's keeping the heat from the sun in the atmosphere, WHEN:

Ice ages, yes, plural. Has froze over the earth then melted, refroze and remelted.

The last ice age was 7000 years ago, and human have only been studying carbon emission for 70th of that time... 

How do you really know if it's "man made climate change"
But instead a natural change in the climate called a glacial retreat..

text: As a student in restoration ecology and climate change myself, I would have like them to reiterate the point that this is a human issue, not a "nature issue". Extreme events have occurred in the past accompanied by mass extinctions before and although they have been accompanied by massive loss of biodiversity, nature adapts and life will continue on. By warming the climate this quickly we are putting our food supply chain and our own habitat at risk, but even if we go extinct the Earth will keep spinning for several more billion years with or without us. People treat climate change as an environmental issue with nature loving extremists at its core, but it is really all about saving people, not the planet.

text:
Great of you to be spreading more awareness on important issues like these :)
Also thought I'd mention:
The most comprehensive study on the relationship between farming and the environment (carried out by Oxford university, 2018) concluded that the single biggest way to reduce our impact on the environment is by adopting a vegan lifestyle. I'm not saying this is the only thing to be done, but it'll certainly help the climate situation, not to mention saving the lives of billions, actually trillions, of marine and land animals that we kill every year. And I'll certainly need to make further changes in future.

text: Thanks for doing this video, very informative and balanced! We really need to come together as human kind to slow down and ultimately stop climate change. Personally I have really started changing my view on flying, it is fun and convenient to spend a few hours on a plane and be able to explore a new country. But it is such a heavy burden on the environment, while there are other ways to travel. Also have been working for the past few years on reducing my meat consumption and that is such a manageable change. text:
Please consider "I spent a day with people who have AMPS (Amplified Musculoskeletal Pain Syndrome)". Most people don't really know too much about it. I was just diagnosed with it a couple months ago. What it is, is a medical condition in which an individual develops an abnormal pain reflex. This overactive reflex causes constriction of blood vessels which deprives oxygen to muscles, bones and skin causing lactic acid build-up. Most people don't usually see someone who is able to correctly diagnose this because it usually occurs in younger people (teens and children mostly) and their parents think their child is faking it for attention just because the usual visual scans can't recognize it. Your blood work will be normal, scans will be normal, and your results will come back as 'you're healthy' even though you're experiencing real pain.
It would really help bring attention to this if you could do a video on it as unfortunately a good amount of people will be told to tough it out as they've never heard of it and a good amount of people who don't know how to treat it yet. I have more information about it if you want to learn more about it. I'd appreciate it!
I have all the paperwork the doctor gave my family with all the information if you'd like to know more about it if you ever see this.

I'd really appreciate it once again!

text: Anthony, thank you for this video. I am an ecologist and find it hard to deal with the knowledge that climate change is an existential threat and that so many species are and will continue to be pushed to extinction. This knowledge often feels incredibly isolating while watching people continue to live their lives as if nothing is happening. Videos like this show that those who care are not alone and remind us that we have so many clever people working to solve the problems. Thank you for the hope and solidarity!

text:
I'm really disappointed that none of the questions posed (or at least aired) talked about OUR pollution vs China, India, Taiwan, Japan and Brazil. We are but a drop in the bucket compared to the countries that MAKE most of the items we consume. You think electric cars are the answer? Electric cars run on the DIRTIEST power source: COAL. What about your computers and phones? Solar panels extract very precious, rare minerals and elements from the earth and cannot sustain entire cities. You don't have to believe me. There are complete studies and documentaries on this. 

What we should have been doing, years ago, is developing clean ways to harness nuclear energy to sustain the world's needs. It takes very little and there is so much potential. Scientists have only just started to scratch the surface. It's a shame that the first thing we did with this power was create weapons of war. You want to be a part of the solution? INVENT, like the kid who developed a filtration system to remove pollution from the oceans. INVENT new, clean ways of solving problems. Relying on a politician, ANY politician, will only result in disappointment. WE THE PEOPLE have the power to innovate. It's gonna take more than the USA though to turn climate change around and the Paris Accords are not the answer.

text: The thing that scared me the most about climate change that people rarely talk about are the effects to the ocean's conveyor belt. Cold salt water sinks in the North Atlantic and flows southward, causing surface waters from the Gulf Stream to flow northwards. The movement of warm water to the north is what keeps Europe's climate mild given its latitude. If the northern waters are too warm or too much freshwater is added, water no longer sinks and the conveyer belt grinds to a halt. As a result, Europe's temperature and rainfall will decrease dramatically (for at least 20 years).

text:
It's true that the actions of a few people is just a drop in the ocean, but that doesn't mean that it does nothing. Because that one drop can become many, they can become a bucket, then a pool, then a lake and even its own ocean. It'd not enough by any means, we still need to change the system since it'll have the greatest impact, but please remember that a small change in the right direction, is still a change for good.
You don't have to become vegan or stop driving your car, but maybe consider having a meat-free day every week, recycle when you can, switch out single use items (you'll save money too), buy used products instead of brand new ones each time etc. Every drop counts.
ALSO, DON'T FORGET TO VOTE!

text:
I do agree with the opinion of raising individual awareness on the topic and let people know their responsibility on it, but I also think supporting and funding energy-saving or -cleaning technology and Eco-friendly alternatives might be the main solution. It is almost impossible to convince everyone to sacrifice their own benefits for a communal welfare since selfishness is always part of humanity. Not that I agree but I do understand how some would see that cutting carbon footprint equals to putting human civilization on hold, and they might not be on board with that. And to change the current situation, we do need everyone's effort, consciously or subconsciously. Ground-breaking technological revolutions might be the long-term solution.
Again, not saying that the video is not mentioning this or against it, but just bringing it out as my personal opinion.

text: The biggest issue about global warming and why so many people are not doing anything about it, is the bystander affect. Basically, when something happens that a lot of people witness, like a murder outside your house for example, there is less chance of someone calling the police or intervening because nearly every person in that situation believes that someone else will do something about it and there is nothing to worry about. In the case of global warming, that is what I believe is happening. We just believe that someone will think of something and in a few years everything will be solved. Sadly that is not the case and the bystander affect is very real and dangerous.

text: As a university student majoring in climate science I really appreciate this video and the scientists Anthony spoke with, its a tough career. I liked how Shaz spoke about trying to motivate people‚Äôs feelings because as humans we don‚Äôt always act with our logic, often it‚Äôs our feelings, and that‚Äôs the key to getting people to drive change. I also appreciated the Geoengineer explaining that geoengineering methods can‚Äôt be relied upon but are merely supplementary to emissions cuts and renewable energy. A lot of people write off geoengineering completely, but some of the less permanent geoengineering solutions like increasing reflectivity through solar reflectors could provide some short term solutions and buy a little time.

text: Interesting. What do you think about carbon fixing? Could there be an energetically clean way to extract carbon from the atmosphere at a scale which would be big enough to be impactful?
author: Mrinal Munbodh

text:
¬†@Mrinal Munbodh¬†  Carbon fixing, like any method of geoengineering imho, is a method that could be used in conjunction with reduced carbon emissions. It‚Äôs one of the ‚Äúbetter‚Äù geoengineering methods as it‚Äôs using afforestation (greening areas that haven‚Äôt been green for years/decades) and reducing deforestation which can help to remove some extra CO2 from the atmosphere. What‚Äôs important to note is that we can‚Äôt just have one method to use, but rather use several methods together. 

Carbon Fixation is probably one of the cleaner carbon removal methods I‚Äôve learnt about, but sadly none that I‚Äôve come across from what I remember (I‚Äôll come back if I remember one) have been shown to be cost effective on a large scale as yet. 

Again, I‚Äôm merely a student of climate so please don‚Äôt take my words as absolute. I‚Äôd highly recommend having a look at the Assessment Report 5: Summary for Policy Makers from the UN which covers this type of information (and much more) and is considered the most authoritative source on Climate Change. Hope this helps xx

text:
Honestly this ain't going to change. The world it too dependant on oil, coal and other similar resources. Companies generate their millions/billions from the extraction, sale and distribution of these resources. Countries such as China are DEPENDANT on coal. 

Humanity in our ignorance have revolved too many of our core systems around the usage of these resources. We should be solving the problems but clearly our priorities are elsewhere, the businesses want to keep making profit and countries want to continue existing without crippling themselves after all. Its a real conundrum, I guess its a matter of time before things really go to sh** and when that times come I wonder what desperate measures will be taken and how foolish we will view ourselves...

From what I have heard we have already done a lot of damage for the future, how effectively we act now is all about damage mitigation nothing more, that is how bad it is already. This is going to blow up in our face so its up to us to take as many (or few) steps back from the bomb that we primed ourselves.

We (countries) are so good at talking about what the issues are, and boasting about small victories but in the grand scheme of things we still are not doing enough, and since the health of the only habitable planet we can reach is concerned - we should be freaking out a lot more! we should be trying a lot harder. 

But the degradation is insidious enough to give us the liberty of doing little and feeling content or bickering amongst ourselves. Its so funny.

It will be fascinating to see the response of the world when things get really bad. And just like with smokers disease (COPD) its not going to be sudden, its going to be progressive, stage to stage. It's during the mid-latter stages, when we come to realise how much our planet has deteriorated compared to now - then the fear will properly sink into our minds and hearts, and the realisation of how we wilfully contributed to the withering of our planet will permeate through our societies. Because by then the differences should be so obvious that no one doubts anymore.

So now the question is, what value is on that bomb timer?

text:
Veganism actually consumes more land area and more water. There needs to be a happy medium for this. I've seen latitudal farms that raise both crops and fish produce more food by area than cattle or a farm. The fish fertilize the plants and the fish require the least amount of food because they live in what is literally a mandatory ingredient for life: water. There are solutions that the core people from both sides want to avoid. 
I love beef, but I am willing to give up one meat for a more sustainable protien and accept more veggies. Hell. My primary source of protien is a bean. If I can live strong and impact the environment less AND still afford it as a baseline working stiff... I'm all on board.
Problem is, things like high fructose corn syrup are a staple of food production, OR the food you are getting is too expensive to buy. 
It's a catch 22. And an easy to overlook problem by people in power or with platforms that don't have to wake up at 3am to work labor for 8-12 jobs just to earn money at the lowest level of the economy. That dollar burrito from taco bell looks way more feasible when you are too tired to cook or too poor to afford quality food

text:
The majority of Americans now believe that climate change is a problem, but still don't really care enough to demand action from their elected officials. Climate activists should shift their focus from convincing climate deniers to radicalizing the people who agree with them but still do nothing.

This is my favorite talking point to get people to actually care about climate change: All of human civilization, from 5000BCE to today, occurred in a period of remarkably stable climate. This stable climate allowed cities to be built along coasts, allowed farms to keep being productive for generations to feed those cities, and let people prepare for the worst-case scenario floods, storms, droughts, and so on. Stable climate was what allowed civilization to emerge and sustain themselves.
 
For the next 7000 years, the second half of human civilization, we won't have the luxury of a stable climate. If we continue along the path most models predict we're on today, the temperature of the Earth won't return to normal for several millennia. We can't live along coastlines any more because the sea will keep incrementally rising for centuries, encroaching on and eventually overwhelming flood defenses. Things that used to occur only once in 100 years, like massive droughts or storms that destroy the food supply of whole countries, will happen practically every year. By 2100 African wheat crops will be decreased by 70% by events like this. But the problem doesn't stop at 2100, it only gets worse. We'll eventually stop emitting CO2, but the climate will keep warming for hundreds to thousands of years depending on when we finally bring our emissions under control.

You can count on one hand the number of times in the history of life on Earth that the climate has changed as rapidly as it's changing now. And every single time that it's happened, the majority of life has gone extinct. In geologic time, what we're doing to the world is of the same speed and magnitude as the asteroid that killed the dinosaurs.  

The magnitude of human misery caused by climate change will increase exponentially the longer it takes for us to bring our emissions to zero. If we start acting RIGHT NOW, with unrelenting pressure on our politicians to sustain the effort, investing literally most of the world's GDP towards solving this problem, we could bring global emissions under control fast enough for this bump in temperatures to only last a century or two. If we don't, the bump will last thousands of years. We have the chance in the next TEN years to control what the climate of the Earth will look like for the next TEN THOUSAND years - and we're letting it slip by.

One more thing - The idea that America doesn't need to curb its emissions because it's only a small part of the global problem MISSES THE POINT. America has a responsibility NOT ONLY to invest the trillions of dollars it'll take to decarbonize its economy immediately (this is the BARE MINIMUM is should do) but ALSO to invest the trillions of dollars it'll take to get the developing world to decarbonize and adapt to climate change. Our country has been exploiting the cheap labor and natural resources of developing countries for its whole history, from the slave trade to the modern globalized economy. We have a moral responsibility to protect the citizens of those countries, who will feel the greatest effects of climate change because of where they're geographically located, but whose governments are least capable of preventing or preparing for it. Since our country is the greatest contributor to climate change when you sum emissions across history, the deaths of people in the third world at the hands of climate change is our responsibility.

text:
The climate crisis is like a Covid pandemic that is ramping up slowly for more than 100 years and is a million times worse.
Both suffer from the same obstacle : an invisible thing that is threatening peoples lives and the future of humanity but with a solution that involves short term economic loss and an honest and selfless participation of everybody . but what's especially vicious and unfair about climate change is that the skeptics don't feel any immediate consequences unlike with covid. instead , all the consequences will fall on a generation that neither did nor profit from the co2 emissions

Try turning off your lights and just turn on a small lamp instead! Maybe do some research of your own of what you can do. Light pollution does not ONLY affect seeing stars, but also affects animals. text:
The thing is the alternative meat industry is still an industry creating emissions and pollution. 
Advance apology because this is a long reply (I am sorry)

I think it would be good if people had local resources, that way those freight trucks wouldn‚Äôt be driving hundreds of miles to transport food (burning fuel) and we wouldn‚Äôt have as much plastic packaging (needed for food preservation). And focusing on pushing pest animals as a food source instead of trying to erase a whole staple would be better for the environment as well by eliminating introduced species which are so damaging to the ecosystem. 

The bonus of this focus is that it will bring people closer to their food and make plant foods cheaper and more accessible because of the reduction in transport and shipping costs. If the fruit and vegetables were cheaper than the packaged alternative people would be more likely to buy them and support the low-impact food than the processed stuff. 

And regarding the alternative to traditional meat, this would make lowering impact of our diet to the environment more palatable to people who want to keep eating meat - as well as help the environment get back to what it should be by eliminating pests which strip the environment, outcompete native animals, and reproduce more prolifically than domesticated sources of meat (in America deer, hogs and rabbits were I believe introduced species and both roam freely and destroy native habitats - in my own country introduced species include deer, rabbits, camels, pigs, foxes and all of these animals are very harmful to the environment because it didn‚Äôt evolve to support them)

text:
Geoengineering is not good for several reasons. (Let me clarify that I am no expert, and I have only loosely researched this)
1. The idea of putting aerosols into the atmosphere to fight climate change falls directly under the category of the God-Species complex, this idea that humans are above the earth/against it, instead of being part of it. "it is us vs. the world/climate change" when in actuality it's us vs. ourselves. Just like said in the video this is just a substitute. It will not only sound but is like we are challenging and finding ways around climate change instead of stopping it at its root. No more excuses.

2.  This is incredibly dangerous politically. We can't regionalize these aerosols, we put them in, and they will eventually equalize over the whole earth to do their job being: cool us down. But if we want to put something this big into the atmosphere that affects every single country, we'd have to come to an agreement with every single government (which we have never seen before). Let's say Russia wants us to put a minimal amount into the atmosphere so that it's not as cold, and suddenly there will be much more livable space without snow, room for agriculture and housing. But then on the other side, we have someplace like Egypt who wants to put a lot of lot more into the air, so it is colder, thus allowing them to have more livable locations that don't cause intense overheating problems. And then we have the tiny, tiny, tiny countries that would not even get a say in the matter and are ultimately left to watch as the big countries fill their own agendas, and now these small ones are in danger of climate shock.

3. Climate Shock is when you do just this, deliberately mess with the climate to make it what you want, it would cool us down and make an artificial cooling system. But let's say something goes wrong, and suddenly everything starts to revert back to before the aerosols are in the air! We would feel the effects of all the climate change we have been experiencing for the last few decades, but this time all at once. It would induce climate shock to way too many environments and species, which would kill them quite fast because they never had any time to adjust.

Ultimately I do not think messing with our atmosphere is for the best. I think it's a cheap excuse to get around the root of the problem, which is that we should stop spitting CO2 out. Remember when the Blue Marvel came out? (that famous picture of the earth) the people who published it thought it would make us all feel so small and fragile. "Wow, look, we really are just some specs in the universe," and it did! but for the MOST part, it did the opposite and enforced the idea that we are in control of the world, and we as humans are on top instead of a part of. I strongly feel this is a bad idea.

text:
A big reason people on the right ignore climate change is that most proposed "solutions" are just increasing government power over the people and the economy. Look at the Green New Deal, for example.
These scientists tell us to vote, but we all know what they want to say: vote for Biden. Do you think right-wingers will ever see reason when all they see is proposal after proposal which restricts economic freedom? We need solutions which do not involve big government. A step in the right direction would be enforcing property rights. Or (slightly) deregulating nuclear power. Even promoting hard climate science (not from the hyped-up media) to the masses would help sway general consumer behavior at least a little. 
Unfortunately, I think the government is incapable of handling such a grave and incorporeal threat as climate change properly. We cannot rely on them to save us - we must do something ourselves.

author: Lisa Maria »òtefan

text:
¬†@MAMMASPUDEL¬† I think it really depends on what city and country though. Like in Finland, the distances are huge and people commute a long way to get to work and school. But even then there are many people like my 50-year-old dad that get on their bikes at 4am and bike 20km to work every morning. I currently live in the city center, so biking to work is much easier and cheaper than having to get a car. And one day when I buy a house, I'll probably keep biking to work anyway, because I enjoy it and it keeps me healthy. And in the winter when it gets too dangerous to bike, there's also a great public transport network with buses, trains and trams that I'll use.

And because Finland is such a "new" country, even younger than the US, our cities were initially built for cars, too. But that's not an excuse, and many cities here have been restructured to favor cyclists and pedestrians. In my city it's not allowed to drive a car through the center anymore. Only buses, trams, cyclists and pedestrians use those roads, and it's reduced so much traffic and pollution. The US needs to shape up. If this little country can do it, so can they!

text: One thing I don't understand is how the world revolves around just the American and European society. Don't you think?
author: Nithya S

text: ¬†@Nithya S¬† There are lots of countries in Europe that nobody ever talks about either. But it's not just Europe and America as a whole, but what it's really about is that the big powerful nations who we all rely on have to do their part in keeping our planet alive, and right now the situation looks really bad. Some of the biggest CO2 emissions come from countries outside of Europe and America, but that's because the big powerful countries have outsourced their production there because it's cheaper. Therefore, we need to focus on Europe and the US, because in order to help the little guys, we need to make the big guys step up and get their shit together. The underlying issue has to be fixed before we can deal with the consequences, or we'll be stuck in an endless loop. It's not about European and American society, it's about stopping European and American countries from ruining the planet for everyone else. (Also, there's China and Russia of course, but America is really the worst offender when it comes to disgusting consumerism and not caring at all about anybody else...)
author: Storyworldofem

text: I used to have regular panic attacks as a child that I would be alive when the apocalypse happened. I had so many adults talk me down saying that "That definitely won't happen in your lifetime." I'll be 27 on Monday, and they're talking about the effects of climate change really starting to make a difference at the end of this century, when I could still very much be alive. My ballot has already been cast for this election, and I hope everyone of age to vote watching this video has already cast theirs or has their plan in place. We need to do whatever we can, but we'll be drops in the bucket until the big corporations and government agree to put the Earth before their greed.

text:
‚ö†Ô∏è Things you can do RIGHT NOW to help climate change down below ‚ö†Ô∏è
üåπ By buying more green products, you're also forcing the system to change since the economy will eventually follow where the money goes. The economy wants money, and so if the consumers put their money towards more green initiatives, the economy will have to follow. 
üåπ Things you can do almost right now
- Eat less meat
- Use recycled paper/fountain pen
- Buy secondhand clothes/furniture
- Grow your own vegetables
- Get a menstrual cup (only if you feel comfortable enough to do so!)
- Consume less in general (you create less waste this way)
- Use public transport/carpool/ride your bike (less CO2 emissions)
- Be conscious about what you're buying (do you really need it? Will you actually use it?)
- Buy as many things without packaging (water, vegetables, fruits)
- Use reusables you will actually use to their full extent (water bottle, lunch box, thermos, reusable bag)
- Buy food as local as you can (if there are apples from across seas or from your country, choose the ones from your country!)
- Ebooks instead of paper books (rip dark academia aesthetic)/secondhand books (yes dark academia aesthetic)
- When you're done with something, find a more sustainable alternative (more natural shampoo, less packaged mascara, basically anything skin/hair/selfcare, choosing wooden brushes over plastic ones)
- Be cautious of microplastics (they get in the sea and destroy ecosystems)
(Will add more as suggestions come!)
üåπ Also: don't give up anything you love for sustainability. Try to make sustainability fit into your life, not your life into sustainability. 
"You can't do all the good the world needs, but the world needs all the good you can do." Quote from Shelby here on YouTube (great source with very accessible information!). We need a whole community of people being imperfect at fighting climate change, not one family being perfect at it. It's okay to make mistakes, so don't feel discouraged. You got this!

text: I get annoyed when people say, ‚Äòsave our planet‚Äô the world will be fine. The earth‚Äôs climate has changed dramatically in it‚Äôs history, believe it or not the Quaternary period (the one we‚Äôre in now) is classed as an ‚ÄòIce Age‚Äô; it‚Äôs actually quite rare that the planet get to experience the existence of snow, and prolonged sub-zero temperatures like those seen at the poles. Yes some species of animals will likely go extinct, but most will adapt, as they have for the past 800 million years in order to survive. I‚Äôm not denying that we have altered our climate dramatically and that we should do all we can to decrease our carbon footprint and lower carbon emissions, (estimates say we have prolonged this ‚Äòinter glacial period‚Äô by 50,000 years) we need to get rid of the idea that the earth will turn into a barren rock akin to Mars, if we don‚Äôt do something. The world will be fine, but if we don‚Äôt try hard enough,  ourselves many other species may not be lucky enough to make it out the other side. Not criticising, I love Anthony‚Äôs stuff and particularly this series; it‚Äôs great for people to know about these kinds of subjects, especially ones of the more commonly stereotyped nature, before they make assumptions and conclusions without seeing the full picture. All the same, thanks for the great content!

text: It bothers me that this problem, like many others, is individualised by the discourse. Of course an individual acting ethically in regards to the environment is a good thing, but the issue of climate change especially must be addressed on a systemic level. The narrative seems to be that you, your mum, and the nice grandpa who feeds stray dogs down the street are, as part of society, to blame for climate change, and thus also have the responsibility to fix it, but the things that cause most of the emissions are actually caused by massive industries controlled by unfathomably wealthy sociopaths who own lawmakers and administrators. Many of these problems cannot simply be changed by a widespread change in consumer behaviour, and many are happening in spite of it, such as continued subsidies for fossil fuels often being the only reason they are competitive in the energy market in many places. The political will to fight climate change is there, as is the sense of urgency associated with, the problem is that the aristocracy does not agree.

author: Purple Burples

text: ¬†@Chloe - Sevens Sin¬† The farms I'm talking about in my town are small. They have all been there for 60+ years. And cows on small farms life good lives. I see them when I drive out of town. They are always with their calves or just chilling and eating some grass. I'm a Christian and in the first and second testament God says it's okay to hunt. My area needs hunting. There are so many deer if they aren't hunted even more would get killed by cars. Not all the animals around us belong there. Those deer would die a much worse death if nobody hunted them. Also, those local farms usually kill the cows quickly with a stun gun. Compare that to the wild where they may get a disease for 8 months before dieing and being eaten alive. And I never said everyone should hunt, it depends on the area. But it's also true with the opposite. People need to hunt it else certain species in certain areas will take over. I also like cooking. I enjoy tossing in a pork chop or red meat every weak or two. I already eat nuts and all the other providers of protein. I also enjoy working out. A medium rare steak plan seared with fried garlic is just too good. Same thing with a brisket or ribs. I'll try and be good for the environment in other ways. However, eating meat and driving a gas car are too things I really don't want to give up. The only electric car I've seen that is good is the Porsche Taycan Turbo S. That thing is $200k. All Tesla's are made poorly and if get damaged sit at a repair shop shop for ever a year. I've seen it happens l many times as my local body shops. Also as a car guy, I like the sound of a v8 too much. And I like to work on my cars and upgrade them. Can't do that on a Tesla, you can't put a twin turbo kit on one of them ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è
author: Ezechiel Dzimeyor

text:
‚Äã¬†@Ezechiel Dzimeyor¬† they live good lives until someone decides to kill them at 2-4 years old, when their natural lifespan is 20 years. what gives us the right to take the life of someone who doesn't want to die?
religion is irrelevant. 
there are other ways of controlling deer population, such as wildlife contraceptive. and the reason they're overpopulated is because we have killed off their natural predators, and while that death would be "worse" that's just how nature is. everyone could die a horrible death at any second, but that doesn't mean everyone should just be euthanised does it? we live our short lives to the fullest.
there are tens of thousands of plants for you to enjoy cooking, you don't need to cook body parts.
doing things that you know are terrible for the environment because you feel like it are why we're in this mess no? we all need to make sacrifices in order to have a better world. :)
author: Chloe - Sevens Sin

text: ¬†@Chloe - Sevens Sin¬†  Yes and no. The reason the deer population is too high in area isn't because we killed their predators. It's because they don't have any. They aren't native to here but have taken over. And the contraceptive isn't cost effective. You could just have people hunt them for their meat and use it. Or you spend $300-1000 on each deer to prevent them from having kids. There other ways my state should be spending money, $600 on each deer isn't a good one. The meat industry isn't going anywhere. And by selling that extra deer all you're doing is helping the local economy if anything. And if you don't want to sell it, you could butcher it up into different cuts or make deer jerky  There aren't any alternatives to ribs or brisket etc. I already use plants and spices in my cooking. I also use meat, I use way more vegetables anyways. For example, last week I made a French mother sauce (sauce espagnole). That sauce would not tase right without using beef broth. Yet their is still over a pound of vegetables in there. And as I stated when it comes to cars. There aren't any electric cars that would be an option. Tesla's have many issues which I already explained. Than we look at other electric vehicles in a reasonable price range. One of the only options is a Prius. Which isn't a fun driving experience. I could pick up a 2017 Golf GTI for the same price. That car would be fun to drive, still get good gas mileage, and I'd be able to modify it, and work on it with ease. That's a much better buy for me. For me all things in moderation. That's why I'm not far right or far left. It's also why I don't eat 20 steaks a month.
author: Ezechiel Dzimeyor

text: ¬†@Chloe - Sevens Sin¬† Also im not the reason we're in this mess. Look at the large companies for most of the reason why. Also if you truly want to do the best for the environment i encourage you to sell your phone, computer, and laptop if you have one. Also go ahead and get rid of your car. And make sure to install $30,000 solar panels on your roof to get renewable energy. Phones, computers etc, contribute to the waste piles of dangerous metals in west Africa. It also need different heavy metals to be sourced for them to work. Also your car even if electric, still doesn't use electricity from wind mills. And make sure you never buy anything from Amazon because of those boxes. You also shouldn't buy an iPhone 12 because you'll need to but a fast charger in a sperate box. I could go on about this for ages...
author: Ezechiel Dzimeyor

text:
‚Äã¬†@Ezechiel Dzimeyor¬† 
there are different forms of the contraceptive, some of which have been very successful. if investments are made there won't be future generations to worry about. for example, the billions that goes to the meat industry could be used for this purpose. even in the case that you do need to kill them, their is no need to consume their bodies. leave it for the scavengers and to return to the soil.
the meat industry is definitely going somewhere! veganism is growing everyday. :)
I've seen many recipes for vegan "ribs", Bosh just uploaded one on their youtube channel even.
not having traditional French mother sauce won't kill you, and I'm sure there's a way to make a plant-based version of it that's very similar. experiment!



of course it's not you specifically, it's the attitude of "I want this despite the consequences, so I'm going to do it anyway"
but you see it's not easy to do all those things, and you know that because you're using it as a way to make me sound ridiculous. 
however it IS easy to pick a bean burger over a meat burger, etc etc.
you're also making a lot of assumptions - I don't do/have most of those things. :)

again, we all have to make sacrifices in order to help everyone.
author: Chloe - Sevens Sin

text: ¬†@Chloe - Sevens Sin¬† Maybe you are talking about a different contraceptive. But the one they tested in my state cost $300-1000 per deer. Also there isn't a reason to not consume the extra deer. Most of the soil in my area seems perfectly fine. It's just eating the extra ones. There are strict regulations on hunting. You can't just go out with a gun and shoot stuff. Also, there is no way to make the meat industry disappear without impoverishing many people. Those farmers would have to sell all the equipment used for cows, pigs, etc and buy equipment to produce wheat. That would mean all these farms would have to throw away that equipment as no one would want it. Than they'd have to invest the capital to start producing plants. That's not going to happen. Farmers don't make much, investing capital would most definitely not help them out. And I never said veganism isn't growing. I'm saying the meat industry will not disappear. Also, there are already farms of both types in my area. And there isn't any benefit to eating fake ribs. At best it tastes the same with less protein. At worst it tastes horrible, had the wrong texture, and still has no protein. And I don't think not having a traditional french mother sauce will kill me. Simply put, I enjoy it. I also see why I should get a bean burger. If I want a burger, I'll have a burger. If I want something with beans, I'll have that aswell. No reason to try and make one the other. Also I didn't really make any assumptions. I simply said do all those things and more and than you'll be as good as you can be for the environment. And I am making it sound ridiculous. I'm also a tech enthusiast, and going into the IT sector. I won't be giving up my PC for a sustainably sourced one even knowing it affects the countries my parents came from. I simply build my own computer, if those metals were mines from west africa. Than it is what it is. I'm not going to live like a caveman ya know. I like the saying bang for buck. And I always strive for it. So maybe someone sells a $3,000 PC made from sustainable sources(not sure if this is a thing). Won't be buying it. I'll be spending $1,200 to build my won PC that will perform good while not being that expensive ( in the realm of PCs this is avg) I try and save electricity by using LEDs. I also enjoy going out side. So going down mount bikes sounds like a blast to me. But I wouldn't give up  a car for a bike. And solar panels are something I would install if money wasn't an issue. If you ask there's a balance. I'm not going to go through college, make $100k + and donate it all to charities. But I would also still donate to Charities. I may save up for a car priced at $200k, but I would still donate money. I would also rather live in a 4,000 sqft house than a tiny one that uses almost no energy. Grew up broke, didn't like it. So I'm not going minimalist. Gonna work hard for that money and most definitely gonna spend it his I please.
author: Ezechiel Dzimeyor

text: ¬†@Chloe - Sevens Sin¬† I'm essentially saying i think I've found a middle ground. So I won't be abandoning a modern life for the sole reason of helping the environment. But I also won't be eating out everyday, buying designer clothes, etc. You get want I'm saying
author: Ezechiel Dzimeyor

text:
‚Äã¬†@Ezechiel Dzimeyor¬† 
there are several forms of wildlife contraception, I recommend watching Earthling Ed's video on hunting.

just because someone makes money off of something, that doesn't mean we should let it continue. I'm sure slave owners had lots of equipment that they had to sell off or repurpose, but profitable doesn't mean moral. the billions that are used to subsidise animal ag could be used to help farmers transition into plant based farming instead. 

personal pleasure is not a justification is cause harm. taste is not more important than life. if you're worried about protein, there are other plant-based options that are extremely high in protein. 

I'm not saying to live like a caveman, but as I said there are very easy switches you can make. especially with diet. I need a computer for my work too, but I do my best to help the planet in other ways.

going plant-based is the least you can do, for the planet and for the animals. :)
author: Chloe - Sevens Sin

text: ¬†@Chloe - Sevens Sin¬† I watched his video. He made some good points. However, I wouldn't hunt something because it's impressive. I'd hunt because there are too many. He says that those predators will have to hunt the deer for ex anyways. So by killing more I'm doing more harm. Normally I'd say this is true, however. I've seen about one predator of deer in my life. Compared to dozens of deer. If all those predators eat as they please, there will be extra deer(at least in my area). Those predators aren't hunted, the only ones you'd see killed are the ones killing cows. Which doesn't happen often in my area. And I understand the slavery thing. But hunting or small farms isn't putting any person's life in danger or making someone's life worse. Animals=/=humans. I don't have a problem with people saying to not hunt whales. Because they are very close to extinct and are not found often. So it makes sense to not hunt them. Unless it's a small ritual village that doesn't hunt many. Deer are abundant, maybe there's a way to bring the population down without hunting. But I don't really see that as a positive. The deer would die without kids, or it would have kids that would be hunted and eaten. Those are compreble if you ask me. I'm perfectly fine with whale hunting being illegal. But I still don't see how hunting a deer is a bad thing.
author: Ezechiel Dzimeyor

text:
¬†@Ezechiel Dzimeyor¬† as I've mentioned there are alternative ways to lower the population, and even if killing is necessary it would be better to leave the body.

hunting and farming do put someone's life in danger, the animals.. animals are not human, but they are still sentient, they want to live, they deserve respect. the deer dying without having kids is the point. 

it's a bad thing because they don't want to die.
author: Chloe - Sevens Sin

text: ¬†@Chloe - Sevens Sin¬† If someone can make lab grown beef with good fat marbling I'll eat it. When I said someone I meant people. I guess if you want to consider a wild deer somewhere near human than okay. I under they are sentient.  I mean I'm not sure how it would be better to leave the body. If there is a more than normal amount of deer in an area. And there are regulations so that they don't get hunted too much. Than nature will get enough naturally dead dear to decompose. Not sure if more than normal would be good in that case. And yes I understand they don't want to die. But if it's a skilled hunter, that only takes shots they can guarentee will kill the deer. Than there will be no issue. They will be dead quickly. But fair enough. However, do plants also what to dieü§î Or are they on a different sentient level in your mind? ( just a question not trying to be rude)

text: ¬†@A N C OVwojak¬† Companies just say they'll do what their customers want as a PR ruse, though, especially if the change people call for costs the companies money. text:
¬†@Ezechiel Dzimeyor¬† 
you don't need to believe humans and non-humans are on the same "level" in order to treat them with respect. would you also be ok with people killing and eating dogs in the same way? there is an issue, a quick death is still uneccessary.
plants are not sentient, they don't have a brain or nervous system. but even in a world where they did, it would still be better to eat plant-based due to energy conversion inefficiency, non-human animals eat much more than we do.
author: Chloe - Sevens Sin

text: ¬†@Chloe - Sevens Sin¬† No because they're domesticated. A wild deer isn't. As I've explained, in my area deer thrive. A dog would not last in the wild. Dingos, wild dogs, etc are different. In fact Dingos aren't related to domesticated dogs. And when it comes to cows I doubt they wouldn't survive at all I'm my area. They have barely any predators. Compared to a dog that wouldn't even know how to hunt. There is most definitely a difference. Also if I had no respect for deer etc, I would go out and kill the deer slowly with a knife. But that's ridiculous, if I want to hunt a Deer, I'll place a well aimed shot that will kill it quickly.
author: Ezechiel Dzimeyor

text: ¬†@Chloe - Sevens Sin¬† And also I never said I eat an insane amount of meat. You must not have listened when I mentioned I eat meat in moderate amounts. text:
¬†@Ezechiel Dzimeyor¬† cows are domesticated and yet you eat them, so dogs being domesticated isn't a reason. there are also feral dogs and cats, cats in particular can overpopulate, so would you be ok with killing and eating them? I also don't understand how an animal would survive in the wild is relevant to whether or not we should kill and eat them. respecting an animal would be to leave it alone, not to cut their life short.
where did I say you only eat meat?
author: Chloe - Sevens Sin

text: ¬†@Chloe - Sevens Sin¬† what I meant by that. Is even if plants were like animals, I wouldn't solely eat either. It's obvious that animals take more energy to produce. But I don't eat that many. And when it comes to feral cats. Unless we are talking about two different things, they can easily become friends with a human. Much easier than it would yo do the same thing with a deer. And also feral cats don't bother me. There are a couple at my apartment buildings. Deer also don't bother me. But if I'm going to eat one why would I choose one with no meat that could viably become a pet. You can't do the same with a deer. And when it comes to dogs. There isn't a point in eating one. If I had to hunt a Dingo or Wild Dog i would. But neither are easy to kill. So why kill one that gives very little meat?

text:
I feel ya. I don't really care about the kids these days, but I do love the planet. I recycle cans, cardboards, plastics, and papers of any kind that can be salvaged. 

I love the animals. It's really hard to cry for humans because no matter who you are, how good you think you are, you're contaminated by a need for violence, destruction, negativity, etc. In short, you're selfish. (Me, me, me. My, my, my. Now, now, now.)

I'm sorry that there isn't anything great for you in the future, but know this: It will be over soon. I wish it wasn't so. We could have been better, but everything is better off without us. 

Even now, you are only selfishly caring for your own survival. You only serve yourself, maybe taking small moments to feed an animal, or wipe your progeny's behind, or maybe watering a small plant. 

But yes, please continue to hide behind a small shield of "honor" that's actually just disguised blaming of others. The bitching for the sake of bitching. 

Anyway, you won't change either. You won't be much better than you are now. You'll just get better at fabricating the false story to yourselves. 

While you wish a friend---or family member---to have a good night, why don't you also think of the planet and her flora and fauna? (Excluding the most spoiled of its children. Us.)

Don't preach betterment. Be betterment. Bye.
author: Katie Marigold

text:
¬†@Blue Skin Alien¬† Earth belongs to the full, biodiverse ecosystems that have kept the whole planet comfortably liveable, and noticeably warm from way off in space, for most of the planet's span of existence. The less of these interlocking balanced/adaptable ecosystems we have, the less our planet will be like itself.

But yes, I agree that humanity, across its evolution, reads like a destroyer of ecosystems in the geologic record. I do believe we're selfconscious and powerful enough now that we might still become good planetary gardeners for the rest of our time. If only the sociopaths and bureaucrats up top would cede some of their power or get out of the way for this.
author: Michel Ottens

text: ¬†@Mariana S√°nchez¬† well I can tell you that: the media is quite wrong. I can only talk about the situation in Germany but you don't live in a room with 8 beds and only get bad porridge for breakfast. I had a quite big bedroom for myself, we had everything we needed and the keepers/educators (I don't know the correct english term for them) became so close to my heart, I still visit the foster home, the children living there at the moment know me all and my former educators are so happy to see when the children that once lived there are still in contact with them because they also spent a lot of time with us and invest a lot of emotions and strength because their mission number one is to give these children a new home and to make them feel safe.

Seriously I would love that. My bio fam drugged me as a baby, but then I got adopted into an abusive family. I struck out twice.

One of my sisters had to eat dog food at her bio home. Another sister got hit in the head a lot as a child and now she is mentally stunted. 

People don't talk a lot about foster care, the backgrounds of the kids, how only babies get passed around because they are new and shiny. How abusive foster families can be and how some only do it for money.

This needs to be talked about!!!

text: I'm a foster child and I'm 17 rn... Elaine (My care worker) said if I eventually don't find a house it will be more likely that I will become homeless... (I'm on the verge of aging out of the system) Every foster house I've been to never really understood me.. all they cared about was the money they would've gotten; that is specifically for me and my financial issues (Clothes, school work, ect) but the most fosters I've been to never really focused on me. When they had kids of their own I find this situation more common. (Foster spending money on their "pure" kid or on themselves) I have developed trust issues over there years so it makes it harder to tell which foster is in it for me because I always look or overthink the bad in them. Enough of me, I think I would really connect to a video like that and would love to see if anyone has encountered any similar situation I had, just to know I'm not alone...

text:
Dude, I've been preaching this since 2015.

Drop your life, dedicate yourself to the planet, if we all do it we revive this planet.

Implement a law worldwide for every couple to only have 1 child for a few generations, presisting with it for 4 generations, in 80 years we would have reduced the population number to 1 billion.

Economical growth doesn't fucking matter, as Barbara Freese once said, the economics that are being taught in schools are outdated, are for a world which is not our's anymore..

If you are a "zoomer" and care so much about your image to others, know this, you are being a selfish prick for choosing your welfare over the world..

Implement campaigns in schools, "What have you done for the planet today?" Implement the awareness

Make people wake up and think, "there's a planet to save.."

Set global values, Maslow's Pyramid ffs, if you have your fisiological needs secure, you should be thinking about the climate next.

Stop seing "your country" and see "your world", its stupid puting this in words, I shouldn't have to, IT SHOULD BE IN OUR INSTINCT TO SAVE THE PLANET!!

author: Poppy

text: Hi culinary and sustainability major here! Going vegetarian is amazing for the environment! Not only does the for grow-for-slaughter animal industry produce a ton of carbon dioxide and methane gasses in the atmosphere, the meat industry also takes up about 60-70% of America‚Äôs farmable land to soley grow grain for animal feed and not for human consumption. The only way corporations speak is through money and consumers, so if we create a demand for more vegetarian options and vegetables in general, the industry will respond accordingly. It may not be instant, but every bit helps!
author: Brianna La Rocca

text: I've heard that it's one of the biggest things you can do to help. Also, it's good for your health, studies show that it adds 10 years to your life. And researching veganism makes you think about morals and ethics too, and makes you wonder if it's right to harm something just because it's not as smart as you. I think we should still show compassion for animals even if we are "better" than them. I believe you about the health reasons though, that's valid. I always tell myself that I have to save myself before I save the world. I want to be vegan, but I'm too picky (I would end up malnourished) so I'm vegetarian for now.  One of the most annoying things about the vegan community is that people say everyone can go vegan,, and if you don't you are just making excuses. In reality, it's a privilege since takes a lot of time to research and learn how you are cook, etc.  Plus some people have food allergies that already make their diet really limited. And if you've had an eating disorder it can be triggering to go vegan. Okay sorry, I ended up writing an essay but I hope it helps anyone that reads it.

text:
Well, as somebody who recognizes the excessive carbon emissions but still doesn‚Äôt believe that the changing climate is a result of this or any other form of human intervention, I would say that the best way to get people like me to help out your cause is not to get us to believe and understand what you believe to be true, but instead to make it much more convenient or cheaper to use clean energy over fossil fuels.

Use the economic system we have in place to compete against these oil companies. Don‚Äôt try to force us to change the system through laws that regulate businesses. That‚Äôs just going to make people hate you. Make it occur naturally.

Also, Anthony, if you want someone on your show who has an opposite opinion, let me know!

author: niktve

text:
¬†@Captain Obvious. ‚Ä¢ 29 years ago¬† : I appreciate your kind gesture. My disagreement with experts has more to do with the reliance on carbon dating in determining the atmospheric pressures and temperatures from before we started measuring them ourselves. I believe carbon dating to be incredibly inaccurate due to many factors, including carbon contamination and the assumption that C14 and C12 have always been mostly constant in our atmosphere before the industrial revolution. 

While I do agree that the climate is changing, I believe it to be a natural occurrence. As a Creationist (and to be fair this is an incredibly biased opinion and a reflection of my beliefs, not one of science), I believe that only God can change the climate.
author: Josh S

text: ¬†@Josh S¬† I dont really intend to change your mind about anything, nor am I religious at all, so I cant really say anything other than that good conduct like that is rare on the internet, and especially on topics like this. I‚Äôve done my own research on the topic just like these clowns in the video and i found all their sources to be discredited by the fact that before we as a species have ever been on this earth, the globe has went through many ice ages as well as extreme heat epochs where sea levels have rised. author: Grant Ez

text: ¬†@Grant Ez¬† Climate Change might be the most researched subject in all of history, and the overwhelming plurality of evidence suggests not only that we're causing it, but that it's gonna cause events on the level of apocalypses, from flooding, to storms, massive influxes of refugees which can cause plagues, etc. Also, the reason people don't move to rural areas is because cities are far more carbon efficient per person, much less carbon is spent on construction, transportation, and other costs, when you have more people compressed into a small area. And yes, the globe has indeed gone through ice ages and other cycles before, but none as fast as this, and looking at past cycles, the next major shift isn't scheduled for tens of thousands of years, and when it does happen naturally, it will be over the course of hundreds and thousands of years, not tens.
author: understandable have a nice day

text:
¬†@Grant Ez¬† As if moving to a rural place is a practical solution. By massively moving to a rural place, people are just going to turn it into a city. Nothing is going to be solved that way. 
Yes we have gone through ice ages and high-low heat levels. But since the industrial revolution the carbon dioxide level in our atmosphere has skyrocketed, we have never seen this much of rise in difference compared to the last fifty years. So are you telling me that everything is at a good balanced cycle over the past million years, then we industrialized but you think it is still natural that the cycle and balance are broken?
You are calling scientists clowns? Attacking the people instead of the argument is not going to make your argument more effective.

text: ¬†@c¬† How do you know what they're feeling isn't legit? You'll never know unless you've somehow switched into a nonbinary person for a day. Nonbinary has also been proven to be true thing by science, along with being transgender (so both of you are perfectly valid and being transgender doesn't make you any less of what gender you transitioned to). All identities are valid, and you can't invalidate what they're going through, unless you've been through it yourself. I can't and won't say being transgender isn't valid because I haven't experienced it, and that they're just trying to be quirky, but I know it's a real thing bc there are so many people who experience gender dysphoria and have to go through the struggles. Being nonbinary is a real and valid identity, and even if you think they're just trying to be 'trendy', then they'll grow out of it, let them do their thing. If they're not just trying to be 'quirky and trendy', then it'll be proven it's a real identity and they'll grow up nonbinary. Plenty of adults identify as nonbinary aswell, so I don't think it's a 'trendy'/'quirky' thing

text:
¬†@Ali F.¬† getting rid of the coal mines. And having those people in a cleaner factory making some form of solar panel, farming, insulating homes, putting panels up. Painting places with more reflective, cooling paint. 

You don't just cut out jobs. The process also creates a lot of jobs. Which usually are less detrimental to human health. Is it really a bad thing to not be under the dusty ground,getting miners lung, which you only did to provide for your family, if you can make money another way.

The change isn't overnight. Slowly jobs there disappear and new ones appear. Which aren't necessarily higher skill level, sometimes are. And those miners that wouldn't be capable of doing things that are higher level, still can work. 

Cleaner air also saves so so so so so so much money in sick days and healthcare costs. You could be struggling with asthma in a relatively clean air place. No smog. Nothing. Then go to like a remote place like mountains and suddenly you can freely breathe.
author: Dutchik

text:
¬†@DR.J0NNYF3V3R¬† sorry. Making an electric car will still have a footprint. But so does the production of regular cars. 
Mining for materials like batteries. Melting steel also isn't something that can now be done by electricity. Because then the wires would just give out. So that needs gas. But can also be biofuel. Still footprint tho. Everything has a footprint. The goal isn't to emit absolutely nothing. That's impossible. It's just the least amount possible. We emit carbon too. And also the more potent methane. But say the amount of methane from cows? Yeah unnecessary.

No process thus far is carbon neutral. Depending on how deep you look. Transport on biofuel? Ok. But the asphalt. And the production of the vehicle? Typically for calculations you wont go THAT deep tho, because it makes it so complicated you can't compare stuff anymore.

author: Jessica √Ö

text: See. While I do believe in science I do believe that on a psychological basis - what we cannot see directly impacting us we tend to disregard as it is not considered ‚Äúimmediate‚Äù or to our current need to ‚Äúsurvive‚Äù I mean on a basis of minute to minute. Now, as I do have a inquisitive mind, I do like to question climate change not to say that I don‚Äôt believe in it but, I can see why people tend to disbelieve- it is easy when you do not follow the masses that you believe this may be propaganda to fuel a paranoid state within people. When people are scared they are easy to dictate and control hence alluding that potentially climate change is a ‚Äúhoax‚Äù however, when we do look into history and metrology we can understand that our earth has gone through many changes and it is our planet going through it‚Äôs natural course- however, climate change is the understanding that humans are exacerbating the rate of yes emissions, and the temperature of our planet. Now, how I would look at this in juxtaposition is - are we simply just speeding up our time ‚Äúleft on this planet?‚Äù As we all know the nature of life is to ultimately die and our planet will one day do this. So, just to challenge thoughts - is it a bad thing that we speed up our process to ultimately die? And not to say I‚Äôm a preacher or in any way religious but, learning about many different beliefs and religions is it ultimately our fear of ‚Äújudgment day‚Äù when everything dies that we are afraid of? Because this does play on my mind a lot. Because of course if we demand more and more and more of a species or natural environment there will be stress response of mutation until that environment cannot handle that anymore and will die. To reiterate - I am not opposed to climate change but, I do think the questions and our concerns are ultimately out of our control - much life if a gamma ray was to hit us. We wouldn‚Äôt know - we would be dead before we even knew what was going on. As much as I am for change and doing the right thing, I don‚Äôt think we ultimately can control death. We are not a ‚ÄúGod‚Äù but, we can prolong life yes. But, what happens when we can no longer sustain it? That day will come. What would we do then?
author: Selina xo

text: I guess I just have some left over teenage angst to deal with? But, it is important to question on a deeper level. How I like to put it. You see a star in the sky now, that star could be dead but the light years it would take to relay that to us we most probably will not be alive to know. But, it‚Äôs the fun fundamental questions of our reality which lead to our quest of knowledge but, in our knowledge we could be completely lost and never know the truth. A bit much of the s concept of schrodinger cat. Alive or dead? We won‚Äôt know but - can assume Is both at once.

I‚Äôm glad you‚Äôre on the up beat of the wave though!! :) it can get better and that‚Äôs a hope that needs to be out there. author: I'll Consume Your Infants

text: ¬†@I'll Consume Your Infants¬† Trichotillomania is noted as a compulsive disorder. Many speculate it stems from family history, OCD, or just pure anxiety. There are over 200,000 cases in the United States yearly. Hair from anywhere on the body is susceptible to being pulled at, but it‚Äôs typically around the eyes and on the head. It‚Äôs more easy to notice during childhood and is often diagnosed in children more commonly than adults. It‚Äôs treatable to stop being so severe, but it‚Äôs highly unlikely anyone will be able to stop entirely. I got psychiatrist who helped me out with it. Many people with it feel ashamed, embarrassed, or distressed. There‚Äôs many videos and articles that cover it, but this is just the gist.
